articles.headline: Where Silicon Valley Is Going to Get in Touch With Its Soul
articles.snippet: The Esalen Institute, a storied hippie hotel in Big Sur, Calif., has reopened with a mission to help technologists who discover that “inside they’re hurting.”
articles.abstract: The Esalen Institute, a storied hippie hotel in Big Sur, Calif., has reopened with a mission to help technologists who discover that “inside they’re hurting.”
articles.lead_paragraph: BIG SUR, Calif. — Silicon Valley, facing a crisis of the soul, has found a retreat center.

articles.headline: Roy Moore Gets Trump Endorsement and R.N.C. Funding for Senate Race
articles.snippet: The Republican National Committee restored its support for Mr. Moore, the Senate candidate in Alabama who has stabilized in the polls after sexual misconduct accusations.
articles.abstract: The Republican National Committee restored its support for Mr. Moore, the Senate candidate in Alabama who has stabilized in the polls after sexual misconduct accusations.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUBURN, Ala. — President Trump on Monday strongly endorsed Roy S. Moore, the Republican nominee for a United States Senate seat here, prompting the Republican National Committee to restore its support for a candidate accused of sexual misconduct against teenage girls.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset, Alan Blinder and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Supreme Court Allows Trump Travel Ban to Take Effect
articles.snippet: The decision was a victory for the administration after its mixed success before the court over the summer, when justices considered and later dismissed disputes over the second version.
articles.abstract: The decision was a victory for the administration after its mixed success before the court over the summer, when justices considered and later dismissed disputes over the second version.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday allowed the third version of the Trump administration’s travel ban to go into effect while legal challenges against it continue. The decision was a victory for the administration after its mixed success before the court over the summer, when justices considered and eventually dismissed disputes over the second version.

articles.headline: CVS and Aetna Say Merger Will Improve Your Health Care. Can They Deliver?
articles.snippet: The two major health players promise better care and lower costs, but skeptics question whether they can achieve those goals.
articles.abstract: The two major health players promise better care and lower costs, but skeptics question whether they can achieve those goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: When CVS Health and Aetna announced their merger on Sunday, their executives painted an image of a dawning health care utopia.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Katie Thomas

articles.headline: How New Yorkers Would Lose Under the Republican Tax Bill
articles.snippet: The legislation could send home prices tumbling, increase the region’s tax burden and make it harder for local governments to pay for infrastructure.
articles.abstract: The legislation could send home prices tumbling, increase the region’s tax burden and make it harder for local governments to pay for infrastructure.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tax bill approved by the Senate is many things, offering a huge tax cut for corporations, lower rates for the wealthy, and a big victory for Republicans and the White House.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Patrick McGeehan

articles.headline: From Bezos to Walton, Big Investors Back Fund for ‘Flyover’ Start-Ups
articles.snippet: The fund started by an AOL co-founder and an author has attracted a Who’s Who of American business to invest in the heartland’s entrepreneurs.
articles.abstract: The fund started by an AOL co-founder and an author has attracted a Who’s Who of American business to invest in the heartland’s entrepreneurs.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Steve Case, the billionaire co-founder of AOL, first met J. D. Vance, author of “Hillbilly Elegy,” the best-selling book about the industrial decline of the Midwest, Mr. Case told him, “I really love the book but there is a part of it I don’t love.”

articles.headline: Google Missed Out on China. Can It Flourish in India?
articles.snippet: As major companies chase India’s new internet users, Google is changing core products to work better on low-end smartphones and use less data.
articles.abstract: As major companies chase India’s new internet users, Google is changing core products to work better on low-end smartphones and use less data.
articles.lead_paragraph: JODHPUR, India — Every month, about four million more Indians get online. They include people like Manju, a 35-year-old seamstress in this city of ancient palaces, who got her first internet phone last week.

articles.headline: Justices Sharply Divided in Gay Rights Case
articles.snippet: A Colorado baker’s refusal to serve a gay couple on religious grounds has led to a major Supreme Court showdown.
articles.abstract: A Colorado baker’s refusal to serve a gay couple on religious grounds has led to a major Supreme Court showdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court entered the latest battleground in the culture wars on Tuesday, hearing arguments in a hard-fought clash between gay rights and claims of religious freedom that was a sort of sequel to the court’s 2015 decision establishing a constitutional right to same-sex marriage.

articles.headline: Tax Plan Aims to Slay a Reagan Target: The Government Beast
articles.snippet: By denying deductions for state and local taxes, the Republicans seek to force high-tax states run by Democrats to capitulate.
articles.abstract: By denying deductions for state and local taxes, the Republicans seek to force high-tax states run by Democrats to capitulate.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was the spring of 1985 when President Ronald Reagan first proposed to put an end to the state and local tax deduction. The idea was, to be sure, politically tricky. The provision had been around since the creation of the federal income tax in 1913, the budgetary expression of America’s celebrated federalism. As Justice Louis Brandeis might have put it, it was the federal government’s way to help pay for policy experimentation in the nation’s “laboratories of democracy.”
